Summary Community builder.  
 
I head up Campus London, Google's seven-storey space for entrepreneurs. At our third birthday in 2015, we'd developed a community of 45,000 doers, dreamers and developers. In 2014, startups within our network raised £41m in capital, and we hosted 850 events, including ~1,100 hours of mentoring.  
 
I mentor and speak on storytelling, women in tech, communities and product, established the UK's first baby-friendly startup school Campus for Mums, got chosen by Oxford University as an expert for their 2012 communities study, and just generally like the internet, people, and lending a hand. Summary My name is Claire Podgorski and I’m a Colorado native, current Californian, University of Notre Dame graduate and Googler. I am a storyteller and wanderer who thrives when I have the opportunity to meet new people and can immerse myself in the unknown. I strongly believe that all of those who wander are not lost, and my travels continue to open doors and give purpose to my life story. I simply want to make a positive impact on the world, and hope to accomplish that by using my own story, experiences and personal anecdotes to inspire others and affect change.

 Experience Community Manager Google January 2014  – Present (1 year 8 months) Mountain View, California I have used my sales experience at building and fostering community - namely internal sales coaching and social media product trainings - to move into a new role where I support Photos, Google+ and Android/Nexus. 
 
As a community manager, I manage the Photos, Google+ and Nexus communities by partnering with cross-functional partners to devise a go-to-market strategy, write launch communications, construct a digital content calendar, deliver product trainings to power users and glean consumer insights based on community feedback analysis. I use social listening tools such as Conversocial and Crimson Hexagon to better understand how Google's users behave and interact online with our brand and products. All in all, I support about 100M(+) community members and visitors on Google's social products.  
 
Notable launches: 
- Google Photos app - Google I/O 2015 (4/5 star rating & 100M app installs) 
- Android Lollipop OS - Fall 2014 
- Nexus 'L' hardware devices - Nexus Player, Nexus 9, Nexus 6 
- Android Wear wearables (Sony, LG, Samsung, Motorola) - Google I/O 2014 
 
In addition, I focus on recruiting and growing our power user base (Top Contributors) within the support communities. I piloted several innovative ways to approach and recruit power users, and I grew the expert base by 5x in just one year (from 7 to 35 experts).  
 
With respect to training, I partnered with 60 other community managers and product support managers @Google to create and deliver trainings to 300 Top Contributors.  
 
Outside of recruiting and training, one of my strengths in building community lies within the realm of expert engagement and management. I attended several in-person meet-ups with experts (including one in London last year) and I hope to continue this in both online and offline settings. Community Manager Google January 2015  –  March 2015  (3 months) San Francisco Bay Area I worked as an accessibility (a11y) community manager in a 20% capacity by delving into Google's external a11y communities: Eyes-Free and Accessible. 
 
I analyzed the type of feedback in the a11y forums and compared it to the type of feedback that our product team receives from users. My ultimate goal was to figure out how to 1). surface a11y top user issues to product more readily and 2). better advocate for users'​ a11y needs externally and internally.  
 
Based on the analysis, I created an internal dashboard and alert system, which Google's centralized a11y engineering team can leverage in product meetings to address feedback, help us close the loop with users and continue improving the overall a11y of Google's products. Account Manager Google August 2011  –  December 2013  (2 years 5 months) Mountain View, CA Google earns a good portion of its revenues from online advertising through AdWords. One of the segments is our mid-market sales team, which balances several million advertisers.  
 
I was able to work with thousands of clients, indicating the sheer scale of our mid-market team and the depth in which we address each’s clients’ needs. 
 
Notable accomplishments:  
- Managed a quarterly portfolio of ~300 accounts and drove $4.3M in revenue/quarter 
- Grew my clients’ revenues by +43% QoQ 
- Coordinated creative process and won a customer branding deal valued at $750K/quarter  
 
In addition to sales, I volunteer as an internal trainer and sales coach. I facilitate courses to more than 200 Googlers on the subject of personal branding. This course serves as a way to educate others about the topic and help them draft a personal brand statement outlining the qualities and skills that they would like to be known for personally and professionally. I was the Senior Community Manager for a number of FMCG Unilever brands: mainly PG tips, Peperami and Pot Noodle. My tasks included: 
 
- Writing and developing engaging content for Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and Vine

- Presenting regularly to clients and, in some cases, being the first point of contact

Summary I'm currently Google's Women in Technology Advocate charged with developing and executing global, scalable programs that benefit women in technology under the brand Women Techmakers. Additionally, I manage the Developer Platform Communities Team overseeing the growth of Google Developer Groups and global education initiatives. 
 
Previous to Google I was developing Ephemerisle - "a floating festival of politics, community, and art"​ as the Arts and Culture Manager at The Seasteading Institute. I consulted for the Institute for the Future where I launched Signtific, an open source platform for scientists and technologists to help forecast future disruptions in their fields. There, I co-led Signtific Lab, a massive multi-player "thought experiment" platform to engage science and technology enthusiasts. Prior to getting on the think-tank circuit I worked with the communities at Digg and Yahoo! (MASH and Live) as an Associate Community Manager, and managed StyleMob, a DIY social network for fashion enthusiasts.  
 
Specialties: mentorship, public speaking, program development, program management, partner management, online social movements, marketing, project management, blogging, design thinking, innovation workshops, prototyping, community development, community abuse regulation, grassroots campaigns, product launches, customer engagement, creative writing, event production, word-of-mouth marketing, influencer recruitment, tastemaker programs, qualitative research, sentiment analysis.
